page.title: 09FARMING IN M.W./SHIPT.
page.content: The Yorkshire Wolds is an escarpment of chalk. On the higher slopes, which have well-drained rocks, soils are shallow, light and flinty. With the help of manure these dry soils produce barley for the fattening of beef cattle. Sheep are reared on rotation grasses in summer and feed on roots in the winter. The Vale of York has a variety of soils laid down by ice-sheets, but they are deep and rich, producing wheat and barley. Most of the farms in the vale are mixed. In the better soils sugar-beet, peas and potatoes are important.
